commentThread.commentText: The problem is when workplaces make assumptions on people in hiring. Younger people are cheaper - not necessarily. Younger people are more efficient - this is definitely not true.

I owned and operated my own business for thirty years. The business is now gone. How do I begin to start over? I have to start another business because I do not fit the criteria of jobs geared for young people. Respect for elders no longer exists.
Try looking for work past 40. Hello Walmart greeters.
My brother thinks most people are washed up by 50. I don't agree

AGE discrimination is real. loyalty loyalty loyalty loyalty . Means nothing. Take away the computer from young people and could they maintain their status and integrity. Younger are important workers but to banned from societal norms is a Genocide. Without an employee young or old we become robotic machines
What an antiquated video, the trans man in hooters outfit is now normal who would have thought.
ABC is a disaster not the law. get the fuck out!

I worked for a company where at a department meeting about 50 workers in a room director told us to hold up our hands if we were over 50. About   3/4 of the room held up their hands lot of us had been there for more then 10 plus years. He was making a point of aging work force but later I realized what he did was most likely illegal.  Not more then 6 months later about 1/2 of those in the room got laid off.
Isn't Stossl getting old himself but he is educated.
Is why you unionize they have to have just cause 21 year uaw member

If corporate Amerika isn't going to hire seniors, and government refuses to enforce laws protecting senior employees, then the age for collecting social security should be reduced to 40 years o f age to counteract the rampant discrimination that is practiced in corporate Amerika today!
Clearly our government does nothing to back up the laws that are in place to protect seniors
This is why I'm so happy I learned to day trade for a living.
Lose your job and let's see your tune change quickly!!
This is what happens when we are living longer than we were intended to.  Society gets all  clogged up at the top.
MAN I hope they won!!!!!  Big time!!!!!
Whiny bitches...
hey hey a million miles to Mark A

commentThread.commentText: It's easy to say, give me a break, until you get older, just wait people.

replies.commentText: He seems eager to reinforce the lie that a younger worker is higher value across the board. How many businesses these days will not hire a worker over 40, but have tremendous turnover and cannot keep their young hires even coming to work? How often do you go to a business where younger workers are discussing their personal problems in front of the clientele? He ignores the differences between perception and reality and claims a person should be able to be fired based on age. Ok, but only if they are losing their performance and not because you think they just seem too old.

commentThread.commentText: Honestly, this is wrong because age is definitely everything everyone would come across. you cant fire someone because they are old. the reason why most of us don't understand this yet is because we are still young and don't know what it feels like to be calle d old until you get to 50 or 70 and become slower in life.

replies.commentText: 50 or 55 or even 60 is WAY TOO YOUNG to be fired.    It's pretty much impossible to find a job after that, and you're career income into social security and retirement has been ruined.  It is criminal

Still, these people have all that experience under their belt. Unless we are talking about low skill minimum wage work (fast food, restaurant waiter, retail worker), marketing work, or media "like those radio djs, and certain TV presenters) then just about everything else, an older worker is way more valued over a younger worker. Just look at how those older workers were able to find jobs right away because of all that experience they got. Younger workers need to be able to build more hands on experience, especially since we are moving towards a time where the youth of today will have LESS hands on experience and far more educational experience compared to previous generations. Things that were seen as jobs 40 years ago, are now seen as lifelong careers today. Most of these occupations don't pay much more than minimum wage, yet older workers expect younger workers work there for decades?!

commentThread.commentText: Most all states are "At Will" employment states, meaning all an employer has to say, whether you've been with that company 3 months or 30 years, is "you're NOT a good fit."  And that is legal.  In the medical field, when a company wants to get rid of an older employee, all they have to say is, "We've received complaints about you--so you are terminated." No, you can't ask what the complaint was, who supposedly levied the complaint, or what exactly was the complaint-----why?  HIPAA laws.  And yes, they can and do---lie. Many companies hire older workers for them to train younger, less knowledgeable, less experienced workers and once these workers are trained, the company fires the older worker, and keeps the younger one.  And that older employee can't say or do a thing about it.  89 days, and/or an "imaginary" complaint is all it takes.

replies.commentText: +Christine Wilson Can't wait for some bosses to end up dead when they fire someone with nothing to lose who decides to go out in a blaze of glory because they pulled those cards.
Well then no point in age discrimination laws.

commentThread.commentText: Are we to become a society that throws you away after you start to wear down? This is your future you have to realize you will not be young forever. Don't be stupid, this will happen to you.

I guess people think that there is a way to not age. The only way I know how is to die. All young people out there should realize that they don't want some asshole to fire them just because they got old. Fuck these companies that just want to use you upland throw you away. And fuck you Stossle, I hope this happens to you.
i detect a conflict of interest in this report - the reporter appears to be acting rather biased for businesses that discriminate based on age
Then why do congressmen, senators, judges, Supreme Court justices, state legislators, who often at over 40, 50, 60, and up get to keep their jobs?

replies.commentText: Eric Barnard true, because ssa isn't enough.

commentThread.commentText:
Sometimes Stossel is an ASS.   He was born in 1947 and has a good paying job. 
As of the date of this upload in 2010, he is 63.  And give me break - he's got to be dying that hair.  It's NOT a given that younger people can do a better job.  I'd rather fly on a plane with an older and more experienced pilot, than with a pilot who is young and has far less flying time.  Look at the pilot of Flight 1549 who water-landed the plane in the Hudson River -  he SAVED all those people.  The pilot in command was 57-year-old Capt. Chesley B. "Sully" Sullenberger, a former fighter pilot who had been an airline pilot since leaving the United States Air Force in 1980.  At the time of the accident, Captain Sullenberger had logged a total of 19,663 flight hours.  He is also a safety expert and a glider pilot.
As soon as an employer takes government money then they should hire and fire according to Federal Regulations.

commentThread.commentText: If you own the business and it's your money, you should be able to hire and fire whom you please. Quit thinking you're entitled to everything people! It's not YOUR job, it's a job your employer created for you and they can take it away just as fast as they gave it to you.

replies.commentText: True. And all businesses should know that we have a right to examine how they conduct their business in our communities and whether we want to continue to patronize them or take our business elsewhere. No "new" opportunities are created though (as Stossel asserts). Businesses are moving deck chairs on the Titanic to keep costs low and profits high. The Cousin Brucie segment was a laugh. I think he's too old to own and run stations--and perhaps older Americans should stop listening to any stations he owns.
Red Raider Okay, but the employers should do the business by themselves.

commentThread.commentText: What a dips#!t this moron is!
I think that Stossel,like most journalists are just playing "devil's advocate" with their questions is all.
yes you should, if its your business you should be able to run it how ever you want. If people dont like that they will protest and other business will take their money. Freedom isnt always PC.
Its not that they cant do things, its the fact that young people bring an appeal thats different than old people. Thats what people want its a business not a charity. No one has a right to a job.

replies.commentText: Dude your so smart

commentThread.commentText: Age discrimination isn't only about age, it's making distinctions among people because of how they look too. Some companies will hire a cute 20 year old guys over someone over 40 because of the way they look. Making distinctions among people because of thei r ag e, sex, religion, and origin is wrong. That is why m any black people were slaves 150 years ago, and women couldn't vote less than 100 years ago. Why Americans can't learn from their past?
Stossel is right.  If an employer is not permitted to hire and fire whom they choose, they'll eventually make the ultimate decision which is to close the enterprise and send everyone home

Basically, Stossel is advocating that it is perfectly OK for businesses to treat people however they like. I imagine if beating employees with sticks were presented as getting better results, he'd be for that too. Notice how he dodges the question about what to do with the displaced people. 
I used to like Stossel but he's the guy who finds fault with things but no solution.

Companies do have the right to run their businesses they way they want. But that doesn't make it right. If I had a restuarant, should I have to right to ban people because they're black, ga y>, a nd old?
Whether if it's because you're old and young, it's still age discrimination . Age discrimination should be treated as bad as discrimination based on race, and sexual orientation.

I think it's just poor business to discriminate. The majority of the reason why older people cost so much more is from regulations anyway. Without the majority of regulations most businesses don't have much incentive to fire them.

Hooters actually took more preemptive measures to help in their case. All waitressess are actually hired "performers", because actors/performers can be hired based on their sex, age, and skin tone. There's still al l black schools where white children aren't welcomed and the government isn't concerned with them (nor should they be). I think if an all-white private school existed today and blacks weren't welcome, it probably wouldn't get much business from non-racist parents.
Age discrimination is unavoidable. We're all going to get older so we'll all face it. Plus it's hard to prove so what else can you do? Nothing.
Stossel enjoys ridiculing the elderly for money. It is like the Enquire on steroids - Controversy, fluff, breeding hostility with no substance

Stossel is a real jerk, masquerading as a journalist.  He is always pushing the Corporate agenda.  His "conclusions" near the end show it, and following his twisted logic, there's no reason why a business shouldn't be able to hire only whites.  "Shouldn't I be able to hire whoever I want??"  It took over 200 years to legislate against prejudice like that.  Get this moron off my TV please...
hey remember that silly woman from alaska who was raised by wolves and lived in a cave , she tried to run for VP a while back hahahhahahha

None of Boeings competition has as good a history of building passenger planes and the same was true with McDonnell Douglas fighter jets. Now that the two have merged Boeing is pretty much the only way to go. They also change the prices of their planes to fit the customers needs. The only way a company will be able to compete is if China gets involved.

That's probably why vehicles have jumped in prices since 2009. It won't make any sense, because CEOs will make millions if a company profits well or if it goes out of business. So guess who's calling all the shots. Unions are the only way to try to fight against corrupt company owners/executives. Do you think any companies that treat employees like family have unions? Most likely not. The government can't really interfere because of free enterprise.

Automotive manufacturing is the lowest demand out of any type of manufacturing out there. Their careers would have ended, because they would have been too valuable for someone else to hire if there were any postings. The government didn't inflate those companies, the CEOs did by counting on the SUV to be the most popular vehicle. They also sold more vehicles than any foreign car makers.

Yeah that would have caused 10% to go unemployed almost overnight and would have crippled the country. The foreign car companies would have taken what they wanted and the rest would have never gotten back up. You are on your own, and so was I at one time. So basically you are invisible to businesses and the government.

The Bush bailouts didn't help McCain and that was more money than what any tax deduction will give you. Politicians haven't done much of anything for unions except when Obama bailed out GM, Ford, and Chrysler. But I am sure that helped him since he helped to keep good careers. Let me remind you a tool is something used to benefit the user of that tool. So siding with the corporations sounds like a perfect tool to me. You hurt yourself to help those that don't need it. That's what power tools do.

Speaking of taxes, union dues are income tax deductible. Whenever our fellow union brothers and sisters run into a problem like their house burns down, or a medical emergency happens we pull together funds to help out. We give a lot to charity especially around Christmas. I am sure nonunion workers would do the same if they could afford it.

The problem is they keep giving increases and they want to take away from the ones that make them the profits, I work in St. Louis. Us along with Seattle and Long Beach, CA are their most profitable sites. We get paid the most too, but only because we are union. The workers on the floor make anywhere from $40K to $80K a year average. The ones that practically live there are making $125K. If their attitude was better towards us, then there would be no complaints.

Boeing CEOs dont really do a lot except advertise and sign contracts. They have a purpose, but the McDonnell Douglas/Boeing legacy is what brings customers back. They get paid about 2M a year, and live off of the company credit card. The President is just a figure head and he made $23M last year. They will probably just shut down South Carolina once they clear the back order of the planes. Since they are nonunion, nothing will stop that from happening.

Yeah that's why when it comes contract time, the rich CEOs do nothing but complain about how much we cost them in wages and benefits. I don't know if you heard, but the 787 has been having problems because of uneducated, nonunion work. Boeing broke the law via the contract they agreed to by moving the plant to South Carolina when it was supposed to be built near Seattle. They made the move to break away from the union. Today Boeing stock dropped $3 a share as a result of the deal.

Who takes a cab anymore? Most people take a bus because it's cheaper. Are you going to come up with more excuses of how things used to be done years ago? You can also do things on the side and not call it a business to avoid taxes, then be able to get unemployment at the same time. You don't have to work a union job. You could easily go somewhere else and call your boss his majesty and have to do everything he says to keep it. Been there done that with over 20 companies, and I don't miss it.
That's also where this evil circle that you call comes from. Companies will also relocate, go out of business, and change their name to get out of fair compensation for employees.

Then Reagan stepped in and changed the laws allowing for golden parachutes to CEO's who fail. So now the average CEO makes 400 times the average worker, the last time that happened was 1929. We have more total unemployed people than ever since then. Now since the job market is wide open unions cant stop the race to the bottom since their involvement is weaker than ever. Then the companies turn the public against unions by brainwashing then through the media.That's why it's a boss's world.

Unions support taking from the rich and giving to the poor. By doing that you help improve the quality of life. The highest percentage of union workers was in 1980. Everyone whether they were union or not made a good wage because union jobs set the bar for pay and benefits for nonunion jobs. At the time people could make big purchases and put money into the economy which created jobs. The average CEO made 40 times the average worker.
Poor people can become millionaires overnight by winning the lottery. Paying for an expensive license just gets you a license.

I guess that depends on the union. Every union job I've had said if you don't work they will move elsewhere. All the laws should be protected, because it is a corporate boss's world once again. When unions go away, the laws will follow. We will once again be slaves to the handful of rich people. I fear it will happen in less than 50 years. It has already happened in the south, eventually the rest of the country will follow.

I hope they do leave and let someone who hasn't lived a life over privileged take over so maybe a fairer workplace is created. If you think labor laws are worthless then research how things used to be in the 1800s compared to today.

I will get old someday. When that day comes, and I have physical limitations I don't want to be denied my willingness to work for that reason. I have also seen older people walked out the door, because they can't produce over 500 parts a night. People that worked for companies for 40 plus years to lose their jobs like that. If they know about the age discrimination laws, then they can fight back.
John Stossel  makes me sick.  He would be crying the blues like a little baby if he lost his job.  It's obvious he is no spring chicken.  I have no respect for him now.
John Stossel is socially bankrupt.

Especially when companies are that big. There is no reason for greed when you profit $68 billion a year. Most of the CEOs are pure evil there. That's why we need labor laws and labor unions to so we can actually make a living working there. Companies big and small are like that all over.

:( that sucks.  that is really stupid AND counter-intuitive!  if they were greedy and smart, they would value the truly good employees who make them money by being efficient and good at their jobs!  if they were greedy and smart, i think everyone would benefit.  

i hope things get better for you and your friends at your job, man... (but that's probably in vain cause i know how greedy and stupid corporations can be.)

They do that's why we have a union. Boeing only cares about greed. We all work together as a great team with all kinds of experiences and backgrounds available for them. They just don't want to give us what we are worth, so we are scum to them. Our union forces them to give us fair wages and benefits.
If your company considers guys like the ones you described non-productive, your company is dumb and they deserve to lose good workers!

I am still in full support of those laws. Companies would want to get rid of older people like them, because they would be considered non-productive. They are a greater safety (cost) risk, and a greater health insurance (cost) risk to the company as well. Just like how they don't hire people that are overweight for the same thing. But, there's no law for that yet. Any law that helps the worker is worth it. Businesses are trying to kill unions so they can start to take our laws away from us.

And in that situation, those two guys are excellent and valuable employees.  The point of this video is to show that making these laws forces employers to, for arbitrary reasons, keep people who aren't always necessarily the best, most valuable workers.

I work for Boeing. In my department we have two guys that are 78 years old. I am 27, and I can do more work than the both of them combined. I make mistakes on the job, and they very rarely do. They can tell me how things were done before computers were integrated into our machines. Since all of my background before Boeing was with computer operated machines, I lack many skills that they have. So with a skilled job, older workers are great for their knowledge by making younger ones grow faster.
this guys a dick
Well said! :D
Employees are smart NOT to be loyal, and employers are smart to NOT expect loyalty. :)

Not necessarily "young workers" more like NEW WORKERS.  The more an employee costs the quicker they go out the door. ( laid off)   New workers cost less for sure.  I've seen an older worker get fired, and rehired for HALF the wage for the same position. Despite his experience, he took the job back, personally, I would've gone elsewhere or started a consulting firm.
Start your own business!

age is not the issue. cost is the issue. younger workers are more willing to take abuse, willing to work cheaper, and cost less for health insurance.

commentThread.commentText: i agree, but keep in mind that an employee also does not owe the employer anything further either. my problem is when an employer complains of lack of loyalty. you bet,hire deadbeat relatives, pay for those flying lessons for grandson, buy the kid a bmw for graduation. all just fine things to do. but then DO NOT turn around and complain of lack of loyalty.

what does that have to do with my comment? sometimes starting a business is easy, sometimes its hard. so what? that has nothing to do with keeping deadbeat relatives on the payroll. why not give those that helped you grow that business a little bit instead of paying someone because they have the same last name as you?

you said "you deserve to be fired if you're still wokring the same job 20,30,40 years later". If its a job you love doing and you do it so well, its no longer a job but a hobby. so why should you deserve to be fired for doing what you love, for so long?
God I hate these younger kids saying old people can't do things.
I like John Stossel

Lol to you, Look how john Stossel is doing, hes giving info to the people so effectively, and by people I mean like you. I want people who can work in my Company and I don't want old people working sooooo slooooowly. And yet old people are expinsive compared to young people, Look you, Its my money and I get to spend it how ever way I want it. If I want you fired cuz your slow, then YOUR FIRED MR.. Suck on that..
Hope mr stossel will like it if ABC or FOX news terminated his position because he was too old.
Stossel is getting a little long in the tooth. He's got an 80s style of reporting and should be replaced with someone a little younger, with more life and lower wage expectations.
Hopefully you'll "HIGHER" someone who can spell "hire." Your shareholders should fire you for your inability to spell simple words. Perhaps someone younger can spell better than you.
The justice here is that no one escapes aging (unless they're dead) and plastic surgery can only do so much, so long.  So those that discriminate are likely to experience it eventually.
employers can be the first to complain about lack of loyalty on the part of employees. does it not work both ways?

hey employers: get rid of the deadbeat relatives off your payroll. stop the flying lessons for your grandkids, oh and their waterski boat with your business name on the side, etc etc etc. and you can afford to keep and pay workers what they are worth. one job i had the boss was paying his kid 100k a year while he was in college, and at the same time cutting our health insurance. sure, it was his right to do it but dont expect loyalty at the same time.
yup. when i was 39 i was inexperienced. when  i turned 40 i became overqualified.

@TheSouthpaw1993 absolutely!  employees are able to leave their job for any reason, as they should be able to.  i'm sure the lefties would be up in arms if i proposed laws against employees discriminating against certain businesses.

@evilillusionist so by that logic, shouldn't it be unfair for someone to leave their job to work somewhere else? the business should be entitled to keep their employees if the business was treating them well enough. also, if an old person is productive, then why would they be fired anyway? what business owner in their right mind would fire someone making them nice profits? clearly, discrimination would not be the cause of the firing, so the law is unnecessary.

@SuperSuzy09 what social responsibility standards?  you pay your employees on time don't you?  you're not lying to them about anything are you?  what else is there?  if you could be more profitable by getting rid of certain employees, it's your right to get rid of them.  on the other hand, employees should be able to leave and work somewhere else if they can make more, shouldn't they?

2 GeneralMills777, I agree that there are limits to the governments involvements in our own personal and business decisions, but there are ethical and social responsibilities that we should hold as a nation, it has been those ethics that held us together during the depression and re-building our country. We need to be doing that now. I am a business owner, and I do hold to social responsibility standards. My word is my word to an employee.

If the older man is being productive enough to hold his own, there should be a law protecting against discrimination. Of course he won't be hyper-productive, but if he's making the business enough profit to merit his employment, why in the hell should he be fired? We're all human. We all age.
ABC your attitude is why America is falling apart.  what about social responsibility, ethics and being human?
ageism, les-ism, transism, speicism a new flavor of the month--Stossel's response 2:20 is brilliant.

@kurthanson2005 Yes, I think you're right. Whenever I talk about starting my own business or doing my own thing, a lot of people ask questions about "job security", as if I have any with a "job". I've been laid off, where's the job security in that?
this is saying fuck your job loyalty does not matter this is so bad if you shit on people. bad bad people.

@maxxpup41 i know this is very late but I just read and really appreciated your and studentofsmith's mature argument. My question is this : How is it that stock prices of a public company aren't affected by the productivity of non-management level employee's?

@maxxpup41 
When I'm older, I don't plan on to be still working in the same job... that's just called lazy and you deserve to be fired if you're still wokring the same job 20, 30, 40 years later.

@maxxpup41 
Give us some examples of the "market not doing the right thing". And what is the "right thing" to be curious? Don't give stupid remarks with no proof.

@maxxpup41 
This is the dumbest statement of all time. And this is the mindset these people have which is why Government is always wasting TAXPAYER money to give money to PEOPLE who don't do their jobs. Government institutions are notorious for being inefficient, ineffective, uninnovative, for the exact reasons you have listed. As a taxpayer, my welfare isat stake and if someone dosn't perform their job in a public company they should be fired.I ain't paying taxes so someone can get free money.
@metalhaze1982 Right On!!! God forbid a nation of persons FREE to do what they want!
This layer can't even win an elementary argument wit John Stossel! This guy is in TROUBLE!!!
@metalhaze1982 What if their business needs are experience? Then old people have an advantage. Do they not?

If I want to fire someone in MY business for any reason I should have the right to.  This crap you get from this entitlement mindset is bullshit.  I have a moral obligation to my shareholders to higher the most productive person for the lowest salary.

well let mister stossel get fired and then comment on it. I know he is a libertarian and in a business sens he makes a point, but how would a country be when employers are free to do EVERYTHING THEY WANT. are they gonna throw old people in the dumpster and let them rot? what happened to ethics and morals? are they being tossed and superseeded by business needs?

In a free society, business owners should be able to hire or fire anyone they want, for any reason they want.  END OF STORY.

And, you fucking lawyers out there can take your rambling rebuttals and stick them up your parasitic asses.

@studentofsmith Public companies fire and hire indiscriminately routinely. Sometimes they get it right and a lot of times they do not. Many people get fired because of trival reasons. I have seen this at public companies many times. It has nothing to do with the person's work performance. It does not get reflected in their stock prices unless it affects their profit and loss statements. When the top management of the company is bad, it will catch up to them.

@maxxpup41 "Companies document poor performance now." True. But excessive documentation of even trivial offenses is just legal self-defense.

While I agree government must not discriminate I remain unconvinced public companies must, by law, not discriminate. After all, if they hire or fire on the basis of irrelevant grounds wouldn't that be reflected in their stock price?

@studentofsmith Companies document poor performance now. Read my comments. I separate the public owned company (stock exchange) from the 100 percent private co. If you own a company, you are risking your own money. I agree with that employment at will needs to prevail. But in the case of publically owned companies, there are too many cases of bullying, firing for no reason, and the person doing the firing is another "employee". There is a stark difference between private companies and public.

@maxxpup41 No business can function effectively without employment at will. In those jurisdictions with the type of labor laws you describe it is customary for employers to "write up" any infractions of company policy, no matter how minor, to create a paper trail so that if an employee sues for wrongful dismissal his or her incompetence can be demonstrated in court.

This wastes resources and damages morale but is the actual, as opposed to the intended, result of the legislation.

@studentofsmith I also believe that workers in public companies and government should have more rights than in companies that are privately owned. The only reason being is that public companies and government have no owner. Only owners of private companies are risking their wealth and capital when employing employees. In publically traded companies and government, the shareholder or taxpayer are pseudo owners and have no rights of ownership, The company official has no risk, unlike priv. owners.

@studentofsmith The market does not always do the correct thing. We are living in a society in which we all have to function. In a way, I agree that private businesses owned by private individuals should be able to hire and fire as their business demands and if they demonstrate that the employee is no longer effective, then they can fire them like any other worker. However, if they have no proof of that then the law should protect the older worker.

@maxxpup41 If older workers really are a benefit to businesses then laws like these are unnecessary. Companies which hire older workers will have a competitive advantage and other companies will be forced to follow suit.

Whether older workers are a benefit or a hindrance probably depends on the business. It's best to let the market sort it out. The centralized, top-down, one-size-fits-all legislative approach is clumsy, heavy-handed and inefficient.

@studentofsmith With the Social Security ages having to be raised, I think age discrimination is going to be a bigger issue. And as a society, you need both old and young in a workplace. The younger workers learn from the older workers. I did. Businesses gain from bot h old and young. When those younger workers get older, they will want the same protection as they complained about when they were younger.

@studentofsmith Supposedly, employers should not discriminate against older workers when hiring. It is very difficult to prevail anyhow when suing for Age discrimination. The US Supreme Court ruled by 5-4 that age discrimination plaintiffs must show that the sole reason for their firing or not being hired is because o f age. That's hard to prove. In the last Congress, there was a House bill that would have made it easier for workers to sue. That bill would not fly in the current Congress.
@studentofsmith Yup.  Laws like this are why Europe has such a high natural unemployment rate.

Don't laws like this one have a chilling effect on hiring older workers in the first place? If I'm an older worker and I want to change jobs I might have a hard time getting hired somewhere else because potential employers know it might be tough to get rid of me without risking a lawsuit.
